Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating the contribution of maternal effects to population differentiation in an herbaceous plant
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mothers can influence the traits of their offspring through mechanisms beyond simple genetic transmission, and such maternal effects can serve as adaptations to local environmental conditions. However, it is not known whether maternal effects contribute broadly to adaptive evolution. This project will evaluate whether maternal effects contribute to population differentiation using the plant Campanulastrum americanum as a model system. The research will integrate observational and manipulative field studies conducted across a latitudinal gradient to determine what portions of variation among populations in life-span are due to maternal genetic variation, within-generation genetic variation, or a combination of the two.

Effective response to environmental change requires improved understanding of the evolutionary mechanisms that underlie adaptation in natural populations. This research will evaluate whether maternal effects have a larger role in adaptive evolution than is currently recognized. This research includes study of flowering time, which is of particular interest because broad-scale patterns indicate earlier flowering in response to contemporary warming climates. The project will increase understanding of the potential evolution of flowering time in warming climates. The project includes development of educational presentations and exhibits for the general public, as well as training of undergraduates, graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher in both scientific research and public outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

Mothers can have a substantial influence on their offspring beyond simply contributing half of their genes. As plants lack behavioral care of offspring, other forms of maternal effects enhance offspring success. This project evaluated the contribution of maternal effects to differences between populations of a short-lived plant. American bellflower, Campanulastrum americanum, grows both as an annual, living for one year, and a biennial living for two years. The annual growth form comes from seeds that germinate in the fall and flower the next year, while biennials are from seeds that germinate in the spring and flower their second summer. Germination season is influenced by a seed’s genes for germination timing, and by timing of seed dispersal from maternal plants, which in turn is determined by maternal flowering time. From studies of other species, we expected to find shorter-lived annuals in the southern part of the range and longer-lived biennials in north. We were interested in the importance of the maternal contribution to variation in growth form among populations relative to that of an individual’s own genes.

We found that maternal flowering time had a stronger influence on offspring growth form than the offspring’s own genes, and that the maternal influence on this trait had greater potential to evolve than the offspring’s influence on the trait. We demonstrated this by growing seeds from 26 populations sampled across a latitudinal gradient in natural habitats in the southern, northern, and middle of the range. As expected, we found seeds from southern populations were more likely to grow as annuals and those from northern populations as biennials. Timing of planting, mimicking timing of dispersal from the maternal plant, had a greater impact on growth form than the seed’s genes for germination, revealing strong maternal effects. Also following expectations, more annuals germinated in the southern garden, more biennials in the north, and the mid-latitude was mixed. Artificial selection on germination and flowering time combinations found flowering time had three times greater change in response to selection than germination time. In total, a mix of experimental approaches demonstrated that cross-generation effects are key to determining the expression of a growth form, a trait closely associated with fitness in American bellflower.

However, counter to expectations, a three-year survey of plants in 19 natural populations from Florida to Michigan did not find the expected pattern of a greater frequency and success of biennials in northern populations and annuals in southern populations. This was surprising as results from experiments described above, where populations were grown under common environments, suggested selection in southern populations for annuals and northern populations for biennials. Why the lack of agreement between observational and experimental studies? Two of the three years surveyed were hotter and drier than average, suggesting that we were evaluating plants in unusual climate conditions, perhaps not representative of those that populations had evolved in. Thus the survey results are a reminder that observational and experimental approaches provide different insights into understanding evolutionary potential in natural populations.    

 

Broader impacts:

(1) The research created a number of training opportunities. Specifically, the project funded the training and scientific development of one post-doc, five graduate students, and 20 undergraduate students, 12 of which engaged in independent research. In addition, one K-12 teacher and one Professor from an undergraduate institution had the opportunity to engage in research.
